attributes.title: Bilingual language use while mixing and switching

q1.value: Bilingual language use while mixing and switching: Follow up experiment

q2.value: Maria Fernanda Gavino, Tamar H. Gollan, Matthew Goldrick

q3.value: The current study is a follow up for the experiment in Gavino & Goldrick (2019), which examined the structure of the language control mechanism(s) in language production. This follow up study is expected to provide increased insight to the two questions being asked in Gavino & Goldrick (2019). The first is: are one or multiple language control mechanism(s) responsible for lexical retrieval and phonetic production? To address this, reaction times, voice onset time (VOT), and vowel formants will be examined in Spanish-English bilinguals. Reaction time is used as a measure of lexical retrieval difficulty, while VOT and vowel formants are used as a measure of accentedness. The second question asked is: to what extent do properties specific to lexical retrieval modulate phonetic processing? This question is explored through cognates because these types of words share both meaning and phonological form.

q4.value:
With regards to the first question, we expect reaction times to be fastest in single contexts, slower in stay contexts, and slowest in switch contexts. We also expect for VOT and vowel formants to be the least accented in single contexts, more accented in stay contexts, and most accented in switch contexts. If one control mechanism is responsible for controlling both lexical access and phonetic processing, we expect for there to be similar sensitivity to the difficulty of language selection across both measures. In other words, increased difficulty in language selection will result in both slower reaction times and more accented productions – i.e. more English-like VOT and vowel quality in Spanish targets and more Spanish-like VOT and vowel quality in English targets. If there are multiple mechanisms responsible for controlling both lexical access and phonetic processing, we expect for there to be varying sensitivities in the difficultly of language selection. For instance, increased difficulty in language selection could result in slower reaction times, but not an increase in accentedness. 

With regards to the second question, we expect for cognates to be retrieve more quickly than non-cognates and for cognates to be more accented than non-cognates, regardless of context. It is possible that control mechanisms may treat cognates differently. If one control mechanism is responsible for controlling both lexical access and phonetic production, we expect that cognate effects will not vary. In other words, we expect that conditions that strengthen lexical effects will also strengthen phonetic effects. If there are multiple mechanisms responsible for controlling both lexical access and phonetic processing, we expect that cognate effects will vary. For example, it is possible that conditions that strengthen lexical effects will not strengthen phonetic effects.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: All participants will complete two single language blocks (one English only and one Spanish only) and a mixed language block. The ordering of single blocks will be counterbalanced across participants. Breaks will be offered between blocks and during the last and longest block. Single language blocks contain 96 critical trials and 112 filler trials, while the mixed language block contains 384 critical trials and 448 filler trials. There are two fixed lists for all three blocks that were pseudo randomized using the following procedure. For all blocks, there were pairs of filler-target trails. For mixed blocks, four types of filler-target trial pairs were created: Spanish-Spanish (SS), English-English (EE), Spanish-English (SE), and English-Spanish (ES). A pattern of eight pairs was created that repeated throughout the block: SS, ES, EE, SE, EE, ES, SS, SE. Extra fillers were inserted by adding fillers after the first SS pair and after the first EE pair until there were no fillers left. After each list was created, they were hand checked to ensure that there were not two identical pictures in a row. If there were, we switched that filler item with the next item that was of the same type. For example, if the English target pig was next to the Spanish other language filler cerdo, we switched the Spanish other language filler with the next Spanish other language filler on the list.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will recruit adults between the ages of 18-40 from the University of California at San Diego community that are Spanish-English bilinguals who are native Spanish speakers and are English dominant.

q13.value: A total of 36 Spanish-English bilinguals will be recruited to participate in this study. In order to be eligible to participate, bilinguals need to be native Spanish speakers who are English dominant bilinguals and need to be between the ages of 18 and 40. We will recruit until we have 36 total speakers’ worth of usable data.

q14.value: A Monte Carlo power analysis was run in order to determine the sample size needed to detect switching costs in voiced VOT for this experiment. The logistic mixed effects model fit to the voiced stops data from Gavino & Goldrick (2019) was used to create simulated data, and the same statistical model was re-fitted to the simulated data to test whether the crucial interaction between language and trial type could be detected by a likelihood ratio test. In the original study, the interaction with mixing was statistically significant. Based on 1,000 simulations, we found that 36 participants yielded β = 0.90 for mixing effects. In the original study, the switching effect was not significant. We therefore conducted 1,000 simulations at varying multiples of the original effect size to estimate what power we would have to observe these larger effects. With 36 participants, if the true effect was twice that observed in the first experiment, β = 0.36; 3 times, 0.52; 4 times, 0.68; 5 times, 0.79. The analysis scripts and full set of results are included in the OSF archive.

question.value: Voice onset time, vowel formants, and reaction times of target words produced in single, mixed, and switched language contexts will be analyzed. More details can be found in followup.pdf.
Linear and logistic mixed effects models will be conducted to test our hypotheses. More details can be found in followup.pdf under the Data Analysis section.

q22.value:
Production errors will be identified by the experimenter while the study is being conducted. Afterwards, productions labeled as errors will be hand checked by a proficient Spanish-English speaker to verify that they were errors. 

The exclusion criteria for reaction time will be a token excluded from VOT analysis (see Data Analysis section in followup.pdf), any production where VOT could be measured but reaction time was not recoverable, and any measure less than 250ms or more than 3000ms. For voiceless stops, any token where Dr. VOT assigns a measure that is less or equal to 5ms and anything more than 120ms will be excluded. For voiced stops, any token assigned a measure of  less or equal to -200ms and more than 50ms will be excluded. Due to measurement errors, any values that are assigned -5 or 5ms will also be excluded. For vowels, any token for which either F1 or F2 is 3 standard deviations away will be excluded.

registration_responses.q1: Bilingual language use while mixing and switching: Follow up experiment
registration_responses.q2: Maria Fernanda Gavino, Tamar H. Gollan, Matthew Goldrick
registration_responses.q3: The current study is a follow up for the experiment in Gavino & Goldrick (2019), which examined the structure of the language control mechanism(s) in language production. This follow up study is expected to provide increased insight to the two questions being asked in Gavino & Goldrick (2019). Reaction time is used as a measure of lexical retrieval difficulty, while VOT and vowel formants are used as a measure of accentedness. This question is explored through cognates because these types of words share both meaning and phonological form.

If there are multiple mechanisms responsible for controlling both lexical access and phonetic processing, we expect for there to be varying sensitivities in the difficultly of language selection. For instance, increased difficulty in language selection could result in slower reaction times, but not an increase in accentedness. 

With regards to the second question, we expect for cognates to be retrieve more quickly than non-cognates and for cognates to be more accented than non-cognates, regardless of context. It is possible that control mechanisms may treat cognates differently. If there are multiple mechanisms responsible for controlling both lexical access and phonetic processing, we expect that cognate effects will vary. For example, it is possible that conditions that strengthen lexical effects will not strengthen phonetic effects.

summary.value: This registration contains simulation code and results for the manuscript "Using bifactor models to examine the predictive validity of hierarchical constructs: Pros, cons, and solutions".

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains simulation code and results for the manuscript "Using bifactor models to examine the predictive validity of hierarchical constructs: Pros, cons, and solutions".

attributes.title: Turning Up, Tuning In, Turning Out: Experimental Evidence from Liberia

q1.value: Turning Up, Tuning In, Turning Out: Experimental Evidence from Liberia

q5.value: Internews Liberia, USAID/Liberia, the National Elections Commission of Liberia, NORC at the University of Chicago and GeoPoll.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In contexts where the private returns to office-holding are high, corruption is entrenched and the link between representative and citizen fractured, understanding the mechanisms to improve the selection of political candidates and how to hold them to account is a first-order concern. In partnership with USAID and Internews, we evaluate the impact of an initiative designed to study the consequences of simultaneously increasing the amount of information political candidates provide about themselves, along with the credibility of the media. Specifically, we randomize several elements of an initiative to hold debates between all 984 candidates for 73 House of Representatives seats ahead of the Liberian election of October 2017. First, we randomize the encouragement to participate in the debates by varying the intensity of efforts to attract candidates to attend the debates. Second, we randomize the intensity of radio coverage of the debates. Each debate is broadcast live by a community radio station, and in treatment districts debates are intensively rebroadcast ten times, at peak hours, at the height of the campaigning season.

q16.value: We evaluate a series of hypotheses using experimental variation generated by our interventions as well as several other sources of randomization in the administration of the debates. First, these focus on whether and how the initiative affected levels of political knowledge about the policy promises and competence of different candidates, as well as general information about policy. Second, on how learning about candidates affected candidate selection and the extent to which citizens vote in line with their preferences. Third, on the electoral returns to candidates and consequences for how candidates campaign. And fourth, on how debate exposure affects attitudes towards the media and the electoral process more broadly.

q17.value: We are conducting a panel survey of around 4,000 citizens across all 73 electoral districts in the country (pre and post-election), which will be supplemented as needed with polling place-level electoral returns, information on political candidates, debate transcripts, and several other sources of data. All estimation strategies and equations are detailed fully in the pre-analysis plan.

q24.value: Harvard Committee on the Use of Human Subjects (IRB17-1178) and NORC at the University of Chicago (7554.072.01)

attributes.title: The primitives of the indexical space

q1.value: Testing shared primitives for person and spatial indexicals

q3.value:
Languages have strategies to categorize entities, spaces and objects as a function of their relation with the speech event. For example, the personal pronoun 'I' in English is used to refer to the person talking, the speaker or the source of the utterance, whereas the locative adverb 'here' is used to refer to spaces in the vicinity of the speaker. 
Lexical items whose meaning depends on an utterance event are known as "indexicals".  We will focus here on personal and spatial deixis; that is, items that refer to either participants or spaces relevant to the utterance. 

Specifically, we ask to what extent these context-dependent expressions,
despite belonging to different lexical classes, share a common semantic basis: Can we analyse both personal and spatial indexicals in terms of an analogous set of features? 

Harbour (2016) has recently proposed that the same basic features (i.e., author and participant) underlie personal, spatial and object deixis. As a result, Harbour’s system predicts that the same constraints that hold for possible person systems should roughly hold for locative and demonstrative systems. For example, if only two bipartitions of the person space are possible (author and participant bipartitions), the same bipartitions should also be the only ones available for partitions in the spatial domain. 

However, there is some disagreement about whether both sets of indexicals should be unified in this way. For example, Deal (2017) argues that evidence from indexical shift suggests this is not the case.

q4.value: We test the hypotheses, based on Harbour (2016), that spatial indexicals use the same set of features as person systems. From this hypothesis, we derive a further learning-based hypothesis: learners assume (unless they get evidence to the contrary), a single underlying partition for both kinds of indexicals. We will assess this hypothesis by testing whether, when learners are trained on one partition for pronouns, they generalize it to locatives.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
We have a between-subjects design with a single factor, Condition, with four levels. 
Each condition (level) determines which combination of person and spatial indexicals participants are trained on. Participants in all conditions are first taught a complete person pronominal system (Phase 1), then exposed to part of a locative system (Phase 2A) and finally tested on how they extrapolate the locative forms they have learned to the remaining locative meanings (Phase 2B). Conditions differ on the characteristics of each of these phases. 

Condition 1. Author bipartition (2+3) for person, Author or Participant bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to author bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the first person and a second form for both second and third persons (2+3).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (1) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2). 

Condition 2. Participant bipartition (1+2) for person, Author or Participant bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to participant bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the third person and a second form for both first and second persons (1+2).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (1) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2). 

Condition 3. Participant bipartition (1+2) for person, Participant or "Random"** bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to participant bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the third person and a second form for both first and second persons (1+2).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (2).

Condition 4. "Random" bipartition (1+3) for person, Participant or "Random" bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to a random person bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the second person and second form for both first and third persons (1+3).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (2). 

Participants are required to learn the full pronominal system, and only those who perform accurately during testing (>66% accuracy rate) are allowed to continue with the experiment.

** "Random" partitions involve homophony between forms which do not themselves form a natural class. These partitions have been shown to be more difficult for learners to acquire (Maldonado & Culbertson submitted).

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four conditions described above. The experiment has two basic phases, each divided in training and testing blocks. Items within each block are presented in a random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk and will be paid 10 USD/h. Participants will be excluded if they are not self-reported native English speakers. See below for addition exclusion-criteria based on performance and attention checks.

q13.value: We aim for a total of between 50 and 60 participants per condition (about 200 participants in total) **after all exclusions** (see below)

q14.value: Sample size based on previous studies using similar paradigms in an online format.  Our size requirement is on the sample used for the analyses, after exclusion based on participants' performance on the first phase of the experiment.

question.value: Our study will manipulate one between-subject variable Condition (4 levels).

In Phase 1, participants are taught four plural pronominal forms. These pronouns are used to express 3 person categories (and their number alternations): 1SG, 1PL, 2SG, 2PL, 3SG and 3PL. 
Two of these pronominal meaning share a single form (i.e. they are are homophonous), and the other two are distinct (depending on the Condition, as specified previously). Participants are tested on how well they have learned the mapping between forms and meanings. The dependent variable for the first phase of the experiment will then be accuracy rates: a binary response variable indicating whether the form chosen for a given meaning is CORRECT or INCORRECT, according to the language they were trained on.  

In Phase 2, participants are taught two distinct locative forms, which correspond to two of the three person categories (relevant to the speaker, the addressee, or other(s)). They must then apply one of the two forms they have learned to the remaining category by selecting between the two options. We will analyse which one of the two taught forms participants use for each person category during testing. For trained forms, this will give us accuracy scores indicating whether the form chosen for a given meaning is CORRECT or INCORRECT, according to the language they were trained on. For a given condition, there are two bipartitions compatible with the training, one of these is always a participant bipartition. Responses for the held-out category will necessarily match one of these two possible bipartitions. We will quantify whether responses match or not the participant bipartition (which basically means using the same form for spaces in the vicinity of the speaker and the addressee).

We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results.
We aim to test whether participants generalize the partition they learned for personal pronouns to locatives. Therefore, we specifically compare conditions that differ on the pronoun system participants are exposed to but not on the locative phase.

- Condition 1 vs. Condition 2: In Condition 1, participants are trained on an author bipartition for personal pronouns. In Condition 2 participants are trained on a participant bipartition. If the person system participants are trained on influences their behaviour wrt locatives, we expect the rate of responses consistent with a participant bipartition to be higher in Condition 2 than in Condition 1. 

- Condition 3 vs. Condition 4: In Condition 3 participants are trained on a participant bipartition for personal pronouns.  In Condition 4, they are trained on a random bipartition (1+3). 
In Condition 3, we expect participants to consistently derive a participant partition in locatives as well. In Condition 4, if participants are expected to derive a similar random locative partition. However, based on previous results (Maldonado & Culbertson, submitted) and a small pilot, we expect the random pronoun partition to be more difficult to learn. Therefore, its influence on locative extrapolation may be less pronounced. Participants may instead derive an author partition (native language bias), may exhibit some other bias, or may simply be inconsistent. We therefore expect more variability in Condition 4 than in Condition 3, leading to an effect of Condition.  

We will run two models, which only differ in the subset of data analysed: Model A will be run on data from Conditions 1 and 2, and Model B will be run on data from Conditions 3 and 4. 

Both Model A and B will test the effect of Condition on the response for the held-out category. This response variable is categorical: coded as 1 or 0 depending on whether it matches or not the participant bipartition on trials involving the held-out (untrained) spatial meaning. Our predictor is Condition (2 levels for each model).  We will also include random by-participant intercepts. We will use a treatment contrast coding scheme with baseline on Conditions 2 (Model A) and Condition 3 (Model B) respectively.

q20.value:
We will encode the responses for the held-out category as follows:

Condition 1/2: If held-out form (vicinity of addressee) == vicinity of speaker, 1; otherwise, 0. 

Condition 3/4: If held-out form (vicinity of speaker) == vicinity of addressee, 1; otherwise, 0.

q21.value:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  We will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the model intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of  selecting one form over other is significantly different from 0, i.e., that the percentage chance in which participants select the held-out form 1 is significantly different from 50%. 

The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more extrapolation towards a participant-partition, and negative towards a other partition (Model A: author partition, Model B: random partition). 

If participants in the baseline condition for each model are consistently extrapolating towards a participant partition, we would expect a positive coefficient. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether there is a responses in the two conditions are significantly different from each other. We expect the effect of condition to be significant in both models A and B.

q22.value:
Participants who have accuracy rates below 66% in Phase 1 won't be allowed to continue with Phase 2. 

We will exclude from the analysis participants who fail to perform accurately in at least 66% of trials of each training category during the test phase. This corresponds to 8 correct responses out of 12 per training category.

q23.value: We don't predict to have any missing data (forced choice task)

q24.value:
We will additionally run a third model applied to the whole set of data, where we look at the interaction between Condition and whether the alternative to the participant partition is the author or the random partition. This model will allow us testing whether there is an asymmetry in the differences depending on what are the two paradigms compatible with the training. 

Moreover, early piloting suggests there might be a participant-partition bias be the case, and if so, we will run two follow-ups: 
1. an experiment design to assess whether English-speakers in fact use a author-partition  when assigning English locatives (here, there) to the stimuli in our experiment. 
2. a control experiment where we only test phase 2 without the training on the pronominal system. This would give us an idea of the preferences people have when they are not primed.

registration_responses.q1: Testing shared primitives for person and spatial indexicals
registration_responses.q3:
Languages have strategies to categorize entities, spaces and objects as a function of their relation with the speech event. For example, the personal pronoun 'I' in English is used to refer to the person talking, the speaker or the source of the utterance, whereas the locative adverb 'here' is used to refer to spaces in the vicinity of the speaker. 
Lexical items whose meaning depends on an utterance event are known as "indexicals".  We will focus here on personal and spatial deixis; that is, items that refer to either participants or spaces relevant to the utterance. 

Specifically, we ask to what extent these context-dependent expressions,

Harbour (2016) has recently proposed that the same basic features (i.e., author and participant) underlie personal, spatial and object deixis. As a result, Harbour’s system predicts that the same constraints that hold for possible person systems should roughly hold for locative and demonstrative systems. For example, if only two bipartitions of the person space are possible (author and participant bipartitions), the same bipartitions should also be the only ones available for partitions in the spatial domain. 

However, there is some disagreement about whether both sets of indexicals should be unified in this way. For example, Deal (2017) argues that evidence from indexical shift suggests this is not the case.
registration_responses.q4: We test the hypotheses, based on Harbour (2016), that spatial indexicals use the same set of features as person systems. From this hypothesis, we derive a further learning-based hypothesis: learners assume (unless they get evidence to the contrary), a single underlying partition for both kinds of indexicals. We will assess this hypothesis by testing whether, when learners are trained on one partition for pronouns, they generalize it to locatives.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q9: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four conditions described above. The experiment has two basic phases, each divided in training and testing blocks. Items within each block are presented in a random order.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We aim for a total of between 50 and 60 participants per condition (about 200 participants in total) **after all exclusions** (see below)
registration_responses.q14: Sample size based on previous studies using similar paradigms in an online format.  Our size requirement is on the sample used for the analyses, after exclusion based on participants' performance on the first phase of the experiment.
registration_responses.q20:
We will encode the responses for the held-out category as follows:

Condition 1/2: If held-out form (vicinity of addressee) == vicinity of speaker, 1; otherwise, 0. 

Condition 3/4: If held-out form (vicinity of speaker) == vicinity of addressee, 1; otherwise, 0.
registration_responses.q21:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  We will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the model intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of  selecting one form over other is significantly different from 0, i.e., that the percentage chance in which participants select the held-out form 1 is significantly different from 50%. 

The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more extrapolation towards a participant-partition, and negative towards a other partition (Model A: author partition, Model B: random partition). 

If participants in the baseline condition for each model are consistently extrapolating towards a participant partition, we would expect a positive coefficient. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether there is a responses in the two conditions are significantly different from each other. We expect the effect of condition to be significant in both models A and B.
registration_responses.q22:
Participants who have accuracy rates below 66% in Phase 1 won't be allowed to continue with Phase 2. 

We will exclude from the analysis participants who fail to perform accurately in at least 66% of trials of each training category during the test phase. This corresponds to 8 correct responses out of 12 per training category.
registration_responses.q23: We don't predict to have any missing data (forced choice task)
registration_responses.q24:
We will additionally run a third model applied to the whole set of data, where we look at the interaction between Condition and whether the alternative to the participant partition is the author or the random partition. This model will allow us testing whether there is an asymmetry in the differences depending on what are the two paradigms compatible with the training. 

Moreover, early piloting suggests there might be a participant-partition bias be the case, and if so, we will run two follow-ups: 
1. an experiment design to assess whether English-speakers in fact use a author-partition  when assigning English locatives (here, there) to the stimuli in our experiment. 
2. a control experiment where we only test phase 2 without the training on the pronominal system. This would give us an idea of the preferences people have when they are not primed.
registration_responses.q8.question:
We have a between-subjects design with a single factor, Condition, with four levels. 
Each condition (level) determines which combination of person and spatial indexicals participants are trained on. Participants in all conditions are first taught a complete person pronominal system (Phase 1), then exposed to part of a locative system (Phase 2A) and finally tested on how they extrapolate the locative forms they have learned to the remaining locative meanings (Phase 2B). Conditions differ on the characteristics of each of these phases. 

Condition 1. Author bipartition (2+3) for person, Author or Participant bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to author bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the first person and a second form for both second and third persons (2+3).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (1) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2). 

Condition 2. Participant bipartition (1+2) for person, Author or Participant bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to participant bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the third person and a second form for both first and second persons (1+2).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (1) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2). 

Condition 3. Participant bipartition (1+2) for person, Participant or "Random"** bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to participant bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the third person and a second form for both first and second persons (1+2).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (2).

Condition 4. "Random" bipartition (1+3) for person, Participant or "Random" bipartition for locatives?
Phase 1: Exposure to a random person bipartition,  where there is one pronominal form for the second person and second form for both first and third persons (1+3).
Phase 2A: Training on one locative form for spaces in the vicinity of addressee (2) and a second for spaces in the vicinity of other(s) (3).   
Phase 2B: Testing on the locative form for spaces in the vicinity of speaker (2). 

Participants are required to learn the full pronominal system, and only those who perform accurately during testing (>66% accuracy rate) are allowed to continue with the experiment.

** "Random" partitions involve homophony between forms which do not themselves form a natural class. These partitions have been shown to be more difficult for learners to acquire (Maldonado & Culbertson submitted).
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk and will be paid 10 USD/h. Participants will be excluded if they are not self-reported native English speakers. See below for addition exclusion-criteria based on performance and attention checks.
registration_responses.q16.question: Our study will manipulate one between-subject variable Condition (4 levels).
registration_responses.q17.question:
In Phase 1, participants are taught four plural pronominal forms. These pronouns are used to express 3 person categories (and their number alternations): 1SG, 1PL, 2SG, 2PL, 3SG and 3PL. 
Two of these pronominal meaning share a single form (i.e. they are are homophonous), and the other two are distinct (depending on the Condition, as specified previously). Participants are tested on how well they have learned the mapping between forms and meanings. The dependent variable for the first phase of the experiment will then be accuracy rates: a binary response variable indicating whether the form chosen for a given meaning is CORRECT or INCORRECT, according to the language they were trained on.  

In Phase 2, participants are taught two distinct locative forms, which correspond to two of the three person categories (relevant to the speaker, the addressee, or other(s)). They must then apply one of the two forms they have learned to the remaining category by selecting between the two options. We will analyse which one of the two taught forms participants use for each person category during testing. For trained forms, this will give us accuracy scores indicating whether the form chosen for a given meaning is CORRECT or INCORRECT, according to the language they were trained on. For a given condition, there are two bipartitions compatible with the training, one of these is always a participant bipartition. Responses for the held-out category will necessarily match one of these two possible bipartitions. We will quantify whether responses match or not the participant bipartition (which basically means using the same form for spaces in the vicinity of the speaker and the addressee).
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results.
We aim to test whether participants generalize the partition they learned for personal pronouns to locatives. Therefore, we specifically compare conditions that differ on the pronoun system participants are exposed to but not on the locative phase.

- Condition 1 vs. Condition 2: In Condition 1, participants are trained on an author bipartition for personal pronouns. In Condition 2 participants are trained on a participant bipartition. If the person system participants are trained on influences their behaviour wrt locatives, we expect the rate of responses consistent with a participant bipartition to be higher in Condition 2 than in Condition 1. 

- Condition 3 vs. Condition 4: In Condition 3 participants are trained on a participant bipartition for personal pronouns.  In Condition 4, they are trained on a random bipartition (1+3). 
In Condition 3, we expect participants to consistently derive a participant partition in locatives as well. In Condition 4, if participants are expected to derive a similar random locative partition. However, based on previous results (Maldonado & Culbertson, submitted) and a small pilot, we expect the random pronoun partition to be more difficult to learn. Therefore, its influence on locative extrapolation may be less pronounced. Participants may instead derive an author partition (native language bias), may exhibit some other bias, or may simply be inconsistent. We therefore expect more variability in Condition 4 than in Condition 3, leading to an effect of Condition.  

We will run two models, which only differ in the subset of data analysed: Model A will be run on data from Conditions 1 and 2, and Model B will be run on data from Conditions 3 and 4. 

Both Model A and B will test the effect of Condition on the response for the held-out category. This response variable is categorical: coded as 1 or 0 depending on whether it matches or not the participant bipartition on trials involving the held-out (untrained) spatial meaning. Our predictor is Condition (2 levels for each model).  We will also include random by-participant intercepts. We will use a treatment contrast coding scheme with baseline on Conditions 2 (Model A) and Condition 3 (Model B) respectively.

attributes.title: Top-Down Effects of Labels in Object Recognition: A replication of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015)
attributes.description: We report a replication of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015).

summary.value:
This is an update on the data collection plan.

We are planning to extend the cut-off date for data collection. Recruitment was more difficult than expected and as of 2/27/2020 we have collected 24 participants. We are extending our cut-off date to 3/8/2020 to try to meet our target sample of 35. 

Because of the needs of the class schedule, we have begun writing our analysis scripts for the behavioral data.  We realize this creates a potential concern that we are extending data collection based on peeking at the data. We affirm that we are only doing this to ensure that students in the course all get an opportunity to collect EEG data. We are keeping the same stopping rule in terms of the amount of data we plan to collect. The initial results from the behavioral data for the first 24 subjects show a strong replication of the behavioral findings of the target article, so we are certainly not continuing to boost statistical significance of these results. We have not yet looked at the EEG data.

registration_responses.summary:
This is an update on the data collection plan.

We are planning to extend the cut-off date for data collection. Recruitment was more difficult than expected and as of 2/27/2020 we have collected 24 participants. We are extending our cut-off date to 3/8/2020 to try to meet our target sample of 35. 

Because of the needs of the class schedule, we have begun writing our analysis scripts for the behavioral data.  We realize this creates a potential concern that we are extending data collection based on peeking at the data. We affirm that we are only doing this to ensure that students in the course all get an opportunity to collect EEG data. We are keeping the same stopping rule in terms of the amount of data we plan to collect. The initial results from the behavioral data for the first 24 subjects show a strong replication of the behavioral findings of the target article, so we are certainly not continuing to boost statistical significance of these results. We have not yet looked at the EEG data.
